name: Pisa
fun_fact: Fun fact: While tourists flock to the Leaning Tower, locals know Pisa's real treasure is its cucina povera (peasant cooking) - like Cecina, a chickpea flatbread allegedly invented by accident by hungry sailors in the 1700s on the Gulf of Pisa, and Torta co' Bischeri, a 16th-century 'pilgrim cake' created to welcome travelers on the Via Francigena!

hero_dishes.name: Cecina (Chickpea Flatbread)
hero_dishes.description: A thin, crispy flatbread (0.5cm thick) made from chickpea flour, water, salt, and olive oil, baked until golden
hero_dishes.origin_story: Legend says cecina originated by accident in the 13th century on the Gulf of Pisa. It goes by different names along the Tuscan coast: 'Cecina' in Pisa, 'Torta di ceci' in Livorno, 'Calda calda' in Carrara
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors throughout Pisa, traditional trattorias, La Grotta

hero_dishes.name: Bordatino alla Pisana
hero_dishes.description: Rich winter soup incorporating fish broth, legumes, pork rinds, buckwheat, wild herbs, and vegetables - the seminal Pisan first course
hero_dishes.origin_story: According to legend, hungry sailors perfected this recipe during sea voyages in the 1700s. Called 'Bordatino' because it was traditionally made and eaten 'a bordo' (on board) boats transporting corn
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Trattoria Da Stelio (since 1965), Osteria dei Cavalieri, traditional trattorias

hero_dishes.name: Pici Cacio e Pepe
hero_dishes.description: Thick, hand-rolled spaghetti served with the simple yet classic combination of cheese and black pepper
hero_dishes.origin_story: Pici are a rustic Tuscan pasta tradition. La Grotta's version is especially popular among locals, served in their medieval grotto dining room
hero_dishes.where_to_find: La Grotta (medieval grotto restaurant), Osteria dei Cavalieri

hero_dishes.name: Tripe alla Pisana
hero_dishes.description: Offal braised in a rich vegetable and stock broth with tomatoes, herbs, and pork belly
hero_dishes.origin_story: One of Pisa's most popular examples of cucina povera (peasant's cooking), showcasing how resourceful cooking can transform humble ingredients into beloved dishes

hero_dishes.name: White Truffle Risotto
hero_dishes.description: Slow Food town San Miniato's exceptional white truffles shaved over Tuscan rice varieties cooked in stock with butter and Parmesan
hero_dishes.origin_story: The Pisan take on risotto showcases Tuscany's prized white truffles from nearby San Miniato, creating a delectable seasonal specialty
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Il Toscano, La PergOletta, upscale Tuscan restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Torta co' Bischeri (Pilgrim Cake)
hero_dishes.description: Soft cream made with white rice, dark chocolate, pine nuts, candied fruit, raisins, and spices in shortcrust pastry with decorative folds ('bischeri') on the edge
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created in the 16th century for an important religious festival to welcome pilgrims arriving from the Via Francigena. The cake's distinctive edge folds resemble guitar tuning heads. Secured a protected quality brand in 2007

hero_dishes.name: Fresh Seafood
hero_dishes.description: Catch of the day from the Tyrrhenian Sea, prepared simply to showcase freshness
hero_dishes.origin_story: La Scaletta, steps from the Leaning Tower, is run by chef patron Dino Ricci who advocates for high-quality seafood and award-winning champagne pairings
hero_dishes.where_to_find: La Scaletta (near Leaning Tower), coastal trattorias

signature_drinks.name: Tuscan Wine
signature_drinks.description: Curated wine selections from Tuscany's renowned vineyards, featuring Chianti, Brunello di Montalcino, and Super Tuscans
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with multi-course meals at refined restaurants like Il Toscano and La PergOletta, or enjoyed during aperitivo hour

signature_drinks.name: Aperitivo
signature_drinks.description: Essential early-evening tipple (Aperol Spritz, Negroni, prosecco) served with complimentary antipasti including salami, prosciutto, and local cheeses
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: After work, Pisans head to their favorite bar for aperitivo. The price of your drink often includes a selection of antipasti, making it a beloved Italian tradition

signature_drinks.name: Award-Winning Champagne
signature_drinks.description: High-quality champagne selections paired with fresh seafood
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed at upscale seafood restaurants like La Scaletta, often paired with the catch of the day

food_culture_notes: Pisan cuisine is a combination of land and sea recipes, blessed with quality fresh ingredients from both the Tyrrhenian coast and Tuscan countryside
Cucina povera (peasant cooking) is celebrated, not hidden - dishes like tripe and bordatino showcase resourceful, flavorful cooking
If you ask locals where to dine near the Tower, they whisper: 'Osteria dei Cavalieri' - located in a 13th-century tower house with separate menus for meat and fish
Trattoria Da Stelio (run by namesake Stelio since 1965) is made for long meals that run deep into the afternoon with sunny terrace dining
The aperitivo tradition is essential - early-evening drinks with complimentary food are a daily ritual for Pisans
La PergOletta has been serving traditional Tuscan cuisine since 1959 with refined, candle-lit atmosphere and flawless white tablecloths
Ribollita (Tuscan bread and vegetable soup) was traditionally the Friday menu to avoid meat, then 'reboiled' (ribollita) for Saturday and Sunday

landmarks: Leaning Tower of Pisa (yes, it exists!)
atmosphere: Medieval dining rooms with exposed brick and stone ceilings
Sunny terrace lunches that stretch into afternoon
Market stalls with fresh Tuscan produce
colors: Deep chocolate brown of Torta co' Bischeri
White marble of Piazza dei Miracoli
unique_modern: Cucina povera elevated to fine dining
Aperitivo culture blending social and culinary traditions
